lessons.title: MLA Works Cited and In-Text Citations

content.explanation: Proper MLA citation ensures academic integrity, gives credit to sources, and allows readers to locate your sources. MLA 9th edition uses a core elements system for Works Cited entries: Author, Title of Source, Title of Container (the larger work containing the source — a journal, website, or anthology), Contributors (editors, translators), Version, Number (volume and issue), Publisher, Publication Date, and Location (page numbers, URL, or DOI). Not every source has all elements — include what is available. For books: Author Last, First. Title. Publisher, Year. For journal articles: Author. "Article Title." Journal Title, vol. #, no. #, Year, pp. #-#. For websites: Author. "Page Title." Website Name, Publisher, Date, URL. In-text citations use parenthetical format: (Author Page) for print sources, (Author) for sources without page numbers. When you name the author in a signal phrase, include only the page number in parentheses: According to Smith, "..." (42). For sources with no author, use a shortened title. For multiple works by the same author, include a shortened title to distinguish them. The Works Cited page is alphabetized by the first element of each entry (usually the author's last name), double-spaced, with hanging indentation.

examples.problem: Create a Works Cited entry for a journal article by John Smith titled 'Climate Change Effects' in Science Today, volume 15, issue 3, 2024, pages 42-58.
examples.answer: Smith, John. "Climate Change Effects." Science Today, vol. 15, no. 3, 2024, pp. 42-58.
examples.explanation: Note: article title in quotation marks, journal title in italics, followed by volume, number, year, and page range.

examples.problem: How do you cite a website with no author?
examples.answer: In-text: use a shortened title in quotation marks ("Effects of Climate"). Works Cited: begin with the article title. "Effects of Climate Change on Agriculture." Environmental News Network, 15 Jan. 2024, www.enn.com/article.
examples.explanation: When there is no author, the title moves to the author position.

examples.problem: What is hanging indentation?
examples.answer: In a Works Cited entry, the first line is flush with the left margin, and all subsequent lines are indented half an inch. This makes the author's name (the alphabetizing element) easy to find.
examples.explanation: Hanging indentation is the opposite of regular paragraph indentation.

content.real_world: While MLA is specific to humanities, every field has citation systems (APA for science and social science, Chicago for history). The principle of rigorous source attribution applies universally in professional and academic work.

lessons.title: Drafting, Revising, and Polishing a Research Paper

content.explanation: Writing a research paper is a multi-stage process. Drafting is the first stage: get your ideas and evidence on paper without worrying about perfection. Follow your outline, but allow the paper to evolve as connections emerge. Write the body paragraphs first (you already know what evidence you have), then the introduction (now that you know what you are introducing), and finally the conclusion (now that you know what you are synthesizing). Revision examines the big picture: Is the thesis clear and supported? Does each paragraph advance the argument? Is the evidence sufficient and relevant? Are counterclaims addressed? Are transitions smooth? Is the paper's voice primarily yours (not a patchwork of sources)? Editing focuses on paragraphs and sentences: Is the language precise? Are sentences varied? Are there wordy phrases that can be tightened? Is the tone appropriate? Proofreading catches surface errors: spelling, grammar, punctuation, and formatting. Check all citations against your Works Cited page. Read the paper aloud to catch awkward phrasing. Have a peer review the paper — fresh eyes catch what yours miss. The final paper should read as a polished, unified argument from start to finish.

examples.problem: Why should you write the introduction last?
examples.answer: The introduction must preview the argument accurately. Until you have written the body and seen how your argument developed, you cannot write an introduction that accurately represents the paper. Writing the introduction last ensures it matches the actual paper, not just your plan.
examples.explanation: Many writers waste time crafting a perfect introduction only to find the paper goes in a different direction.

examples.problem: What is the difference between revision and editing?
examples.answer: Revision is rethinking the content and structure — reordering paragraphs, strengthening arguments, cutting irrelevant sections, adding evidence. Editing is refining language — improving sentences, fixing word choice, tightening prose. Revision changes what you say; editing changes how you say it.
examples.explanation: Always revise before you edit — there is no point polishing sentences in a paragraph you might cut.

examples.problem: How do you ensure the paper sounds like you, not a patchwork of sources?
examples.answer: Your voice should frame every source: introduce it, present it, analyze it. If you remove all the quotations and paraphrases, the remaining text should still read as a coherent argument in your voice. If removing sources leaves nothing, the paper is too source-dependent.
examples.explanation: The paper is your argument, supported by sources. It is not a report of what sources say.

content.real_world: The ability to produce polished, professional documents through a systematic revision process is one of the most valuable skills in any career. Every important document — from business plans to legal briefs — goes through multiple drafts.

units.title: Vocabulary and SAT Prep
units.description: Build vocabulary through context clues, word roots, academic vocabulary, and strategic test-taking skills.

content.explanation: Strong vocabulary is built through reading and through strategies for deciphering unfamiliar words. Context clues — information surrounding an unknown word — are the most powerful tool for determining meaning. There are several types. Definition clues directly define the word: 'The patient was lethargic, meaning abnormally drowsy and sluggish.' Synonym clues provide a word with similar meaning nearby: 'The speaker was eloquent, articulate and persuasive in her arguments.' Antonym clues provide a contrasting word: 'Unlike his gregarious brother, Tom was reserved and preferred solitude.' Example clues illustrate the word's meaning: 'Nocturnal animals, such as owls, bats, and raccoons, are active at night.' Inference clues require you to use the broader context to reason about meaning: 'After weeks of drought, the desiccated landscape stretched endlessly — cracked earth, dead grass, withered trees.' Tone and connotation clues use the surrounding emotional context: if a word appears in a negative context ('the politician's specious argument fooled no one'), it likely has a negative meaning. Practice using these strategies actively while reading, and you will build vocabulary naturally.

examples.problem: Determine the meaning of 'obsequious' from context: 'The obsequious waiter hovered constantly, complimenting everything we said and rushing to refill glasses that were barely touched.'
examples.answer: Excessively eager to serve and please — the context clues (hovering, constant complimenting, rushing to refill) suggest overly attentive, fawning behavior.
examples.explanation: The combination of actions described paints a clear picture of the word's meaning.

examples.problem: Use an antonym clue: 'While Maria was pragmatic and focused on practical solutions, her partner was idealistic, more concerned with principles than results.'
examples.answer: 'Pragmatic' means practical and focused on real-world results, as opposed to 'idealistic.' The contrast word 'while' signals that the two terms are antonyms.
examples.explanation: Words like 'while,' 'unlike,' 'but,' 'however,' and 'in contrast' often signal antonym clues.

examples.problem: Use inference to determine the meaning of 'ephemeral': 'Cherry blossoms are ephemeral — their beauty lasts only days before the petals scatter in the wind.'
examples.answer: 'Ephemeral' means lasting only a short time. The clue 'lasts only days before the petals scatter' indicates brevity and transience.
examples.explanation: The em-dash introduces an explanation that clarifies the word's meaning.

content.real_world: Research shows that most vocabulary is learned through reading, not memorization. Active readers who use context clues build vocabulary 10 times faster than those who only study word lists. Reading widely is the single best vocabulary-building strategy.

options: A word with the same meaning
A word with the opposite meaning

options: A synonym clue providing a similar meaning to 'eloquent'

content.explanation: Understanding word parts — roots, prefixes, and suffixes — allows you to decode thousands of unfamiliar words. A root is the core meaning of a word, often derived from Latin or Greek. A prefix is added before the root to modify meaning. A suffix is added after the root, often changing the word's part of speech. Key Latin roots: dict (say/speak: predict, dictate, verdict), scrib/script (write: describe, manuscript, prescription), port (carry: transport, import, portable), rupt (break: interrupt, corrupt, eruption), spec/spect (see/look: inspect, spectacle, perspective), and ced/cess (go/yield: proceed, access, exceed). Key Greek roots: graph (write: biography, photography), logos (word/study: biology, psychology), chronos (time: chronological, synchronize), phon (sound: telephone, symphony), and path (feeling/suffering: sympathy, pathology). Key prefixes: un/in/im/ir/il (not), re (again), pre (before), post (after), anti (against), mis (wrong), over (excess), under (below/insufficient). Key suffixes: -tion/-sion (act of), -ous/-ious (full of), -able/-ible (capable of), -ment (state of), -ity (quality of). When encountering an unknown word, break it into parts and combine the meanings.

examples.problem: Break down the word 'unprecedented.'
examples.answer: Un- (not) + pre- (before) + ced (go) + -ent (adjective suffix) + -ed = not gone before = never having happened or existed before. Something unprecedented has no prior example.
examples.explanation: Breaking a word into parts often reveals its meaning even if you have never seen it before.

examples.problem: What does 'chronological' mean based on its roots?
examples.answer: Chrono (time) + -logical (relating to the study of) = relating to the order of time. Chronological order means arranged by time sequence, from earliest to latest.
examples.explanation: Knowing 'chronos' helps you understand chronometer, chronicle, chronic, synchronize, and anachronism.

examples.problem: Use roots to determine the meaning of 'malevolent.'
examples.answer: Mal- (bad/evil) + vol (wish/will) + -ent (adjective) = wishing evil. Malevolent means having or showing a desire to do harm to others.
examples.explanation: Knowing 'mal' helps with malice, malfunction, malpractice, malicious, and malady.

content.real_world: Medical, legal, and scientific terminology is built from Latin and Greek roots. A doctor who knows 'cardio' (heart), 'pulmon' (lung), and '-itis' (inflammation) can decode thousands of medical terms. Root knowledge is a professional superpower.

content.explanation: Academic vocabulary consists of the words used across disciplines in scholarly, professional, and formal contexts. These words are different from everyday vocabulary and from subject-specific technical terms. They appear in textbooks, essays, standardized tests, and professional communication across all fields. Key academic words include: analyze (examine in detail to understand structure or meaning), synthesize (combine elements to form a new whole), evaluate (assess the value or quality), infer (draw conclusions from evidence), cite (refer to as evidence or authority), assert (state confidently as fact), refute (prove wrong), corroborate (confirm or support), juxtapose (place side by side for comparison), implicit (implied but not directly stated), explicit (clearly and directly stated), ambiguous (open to multiple interpretations), comprehensive (thorough, covering all aspects), substantiate (provide evidence to support), and mitigate (make less severe). Learning these words is not about memorizing definitions — it is about understanding how they function in academic discourse. These words represent academic thinking: analyzing, evaluating, synthesizing, and arguing are the core operations of scholarship.

examples.problem: What is the difference between 'implicit' and 'explicit'?
examples.answer: 'Explicit' means directly and clearly stated ('The rules explicitly prohibit phones in class'). 'Implicit' means implied or suggested but not directly stated ('Her smile implicitly communicated approval'). The difference is between direct statement and indirect suggestion.
examples.explanation: In literature, explicit meaning is what the text says; implicit meaning is what it suggests beneath the surface.

examples.problem: How do 'analyze' and 'synthesize' differ?
examples.answer: 'Analyze' means to break something into parts to understand its structure. 'Synthesize' means to combine parts to form a new understanding. Analysis takes apart; synthesis puts together. A research paper analyzes individual sources and synthesizes their findings into an original argument.
examples.explanation: These are complementary operations — analysis informs synthesis, and synthesis gives purpose to analysis.

examples.problem: Use 'corroborate' in a sentence that demonstrates its meaning.
examples.answer: 'The witness's testimony was corroborated by security camera footage, confirming her account of events.' Corroborate means to confirm or support with additional evidence.
examples.explanation: In academic writing, you corroborate claims by providing multiple sources that support the same conclusion.

content.real_world: Academic vocabulary is the language of professional success. Whether you enter medicine, law, business, technology, or education, the ability to use these words precisely signals competence and clear thinking.

lessons.title: Test-Taking Strategies for Reading and Writing

content.explanation: Standardized tests like the SAT and ACT assess reading comprehension, vocabulary in context, and writing skills. Effective test-taking combines content knowledge with strategic approaches. For reading passages: preview the questions first to know what to look for, then read actively, annotating key ideas, evidence, and transitions. Answer questions based on what the text says, not your outside knowledge or opinions. For vocabulary-in-context questions: always check the specific context — words often have secondary meanings that differ from their primary definition. Substitute each answer choice into the sentence to see which fits. For evidence-based questions: choose the answer that is directly supported by the text, not the one that sounds smartest or most complicated. Watch for trap answers that are true in general but not supported by the specific passage. For writing and language questions: read the entire sentence and surrounding sentences before choosing. Consider not just grammar but also style, tone, and logical flow. For essay prompts: plan before writing (5 minutes of planning saves 15 minutes of confusion), use specific evidence, and structure clearly with an introduction, body, and conclusion. Time management is critical: allocate time per section, do not spend too long on any single question, and always answer every question (there is no penalty for guessing on most modern tests).

examples.problem: Why should you preview questions before reading a test passage?
examples.answer: Previewing tells you what to look for while reading — specific details, main ideas, author's purpose, vocabulary in context. This focused reading is more efficient than reading blindly and then hunting for answers.
examples.explanation: Think of questions as a treasure map — they tell you what the 'treasure' (correct answers) will look like.

examples.problem: What is a 'trap answer' on a reading test?
examples.answer: A trap answer is an option that is true in general or sounds reasonable but is not supported by the specific passage. It exploits the test-taker's tendency to choose what they know rather than what the text says. Always ask: 'Can I point to specific text that supports this answer?'
examples.explanation: The correct answer is always provable with textual evidence; trap answers rely on outside knowledge or assumptions.

examples.problem: How should you approach vocabulary-in-context questions?
examples.answer: Read the sentence carefully, substitute each answer choice into the sentence, and choose the one that preserves the sentence's meaning. Many vocabulary questions use common words with uncommon meanings — 'grave' might mean 'serious' rather than 'burial place.' Context determines meaning.
examples.explanation: Never assume you know the answer without checking the context — tests deliberately use secondary meanings.

content.real_world: Test-taking strategies are life skills in disguise. Reading carefully, supporting answers with evidence, managing time, and eliminating wrong options are skills used in job interviews, professional examinations, and any situation requiring careful analysis under pressure.
